but perhaps not hold so long. For when they hear of it in the country then they will send them up from Canterb[ury] & Maidston whereas this week it being dull there were but few brought up that I heard of. My Remembrances where due. I am Your ever Lo: husband Sa: Jeake.

Keep the eyebright from growing mouldy.” If Mr Manooch ask about his dividend tell him Mr Miller has received it & assoon as I come home shall have it.

Tell John Dickson I have now received all his money of Mr Eyre & when I come home shall either pay him or continue it at Inte[rest as] best suites his & my occasion.

To Mrs Elizabeth Jeake at Rye in Sussex

[232] Samuel Jeake junior to Elizabeth Jeake, 2 October 1697. Original letter. ESRO FRE 5311

London Oct .2. 1697

My Dear In answer to yours of the 30" past. You may enquire among the shopkeepers & assoon as you will draw Thirty pounds on me & write your bill thus Rye Oct: th 1697. per £30

At three days sight hereof pay to Mr A.B. or order the summe of Thirty Pounds Sterling value of himself as per advice of Your Lo: Wife E: J. ToS Jat Mr T Ms mercht" in Dunster Court Mincing Lane London

* Euphrasia officinalis, more commonly known as ‘eyebright’, was a popular remedy for weak eyes, something which Samuel had suffered from since contracting smallpox during his teens. DTGC, ‘Etruscan — Eyebright water’. "Thomas Miller, merchant.
